title: Hello World: My Journey to Java, Open Source, and Ubuntu
content:
Starting a career in software engineering feels a lot like writing your first program. You begin with a simple "Hello World," and suddenly, a whole universe of possibilities opens up.

Today, I’m writing my "Hello World" blog post to share my journey as I build my path toward becoming a remote software engineer.

Why Java and Why Remote?

I chose Java because it is the backbone of so many systems I admire. It’s structured, powerful, and has a massive community.

My goal is to work remotely, not just for the flexibility, but because remote work allows you to collaborate with the best minds across the globe, regardless of where you are.

The Dream: Contributing to Ubuntu

If there’s one place I truly want to make an impact, it’s Ubuntu. I’ve always admired how Ubuntu makes Linux accessible to everyone. My career objective is to contribute to open-source projects that align with this mission.

Right now, I am:

  • Strengthening my Java skills: Moving beyond the basics into more complex applications.
  • Mastering DSA: Solving problems daily to sharpen my logic (and keeping my code organized with clean headers!).
  • Learning Open Source Etiquette: Writing industry-standard commit messages like feat: and docs: because clear communication is just as important as clean code.

What’s Next?

I’m currently looking for beginner-friendly open-source projects in Java where I can help. I believe that the best way to learn is by doing—and the best way to grow is by contributing to something bigger than yourself.

If you’re a recruiter at Canonical, an open-source contributor, or a fellow Java developer, I’d love to connect. I’m ready to learn, code, and contribute.
